name.value: Die Lieben Sieben: Auf dem Jahrmarkt

item.description:
The game board is a sliding lane with six fields, each showing a fun fair attraction. At the end of the field, there are three wooden "tin cans" stacked up.
The active player draws a card and tries to slide the marble slider onto the corresponding field. If successful, s/he gets the card. For two of the same cards, the player gets a free ride chip. If the player flips up the tin can card, s/he has to try to topple the three tin cans to get a free ride; if unsuccessful, the other players can try (in clockwise order).
At the end of the game, the player with most chips is the winner.

Simple roll and move game to the moon and back, with the objective to be first back

Graphics similar to Dan Dare type rockets and space vehicles and probably dated around mid 1950s

Published by Holdson products, New Zealand

name.value: Angry Birds: Star Wars – Jenga Tatooine Battle Game

item.description:
This game one of the many games in the Angry Birds Series.

Take turns bombarding the porky kingpin in the sandblasted terrain of Tatoonie (back of box.) "Roll, Launch, Win"

This is a new edition to the Jenga & Angry Birds line. The game comes with a Luke Skywalker bird, a Jabba the Hutt pig, a Rancor pig, a Millennium Falcon launcher, 12 plastic Jenga blocks, 2 dice, label sheet, and game guide. The object of the game is to launch birds and knock down pigs to score the most points. One player is the builder, and the other player is the launcher. You score 1000 points for each pig you knock completely off the structure. In addition, you score a bonus 1000 points if you have any birds left unlaunched after you knock all the pigs off. Take turns until you've played three rounds. If you scored the highest, you win!

The game is based on the Star Wars Angry Bird app. In addition, the game comes with a App code to unlock game content.

In Hostage Negotiator, you play the part of a law enforcement agent responsible for negotiating the release of hostages taken by an unscrupulous figure hell-bent on having his or her demands met.

Each turn in the game represents a conversation between you and the hostage taker. You'll play cards and roll dice to increase conversation points, decrease the threat level, and release hostages. Hostage Negotiator uses a unique "hand-building" mechanism that puts cards you purchase directly in your hand for next turn rather than leaving you wondering when the cards will show up like in deck-building games.

In Hostage Negotiator there are multiple paths to victory, but the hostage taker has other plans. Will you try to calm him and get him to surrender? Will you stall and bide your time before sending in the team for a major extraction? How many hostages will you save? These are many of the exciting decisions you will make in a game of Hostage Negotiator!

This game one of the many games in the Angry Birds Series.

Take turns bombarding an imperial hog in the frozen terrain of Hoth (from back of box.) "Roll, Launch, Win!"

This is a new edition to the Jenga & Angry Birds line. The game comes with a Luke Skywalker bird, 2 Snowtrooper pigs, a Snowspeeder launcher, 12 translucent plastic Jenga blocks, 2 dice, label sheet, and game guide. The object of the game is to launch birds and knock down pigs to score the most points. One player is the builder, and the other player is the launcher. You score 1000 points for each pig you knock completely off the structure. In addition, you score a bonus 1000 points if you have any birds left unlaunched after you knock all the pigs off. Take turns until you've played three rounds. If you scored the highest, you win!

The game is based on the Star Wars Angry Bird app. In addition, the game comes with a App code to unlock game content.

name.value: Angry Birds: Star Wars – Jenga Death Star Game

item.description:
This game one of the many games in the Angry Birds Series.

Darth Vader and his porky enforcers are ready for an intergalactic battle. Take turns trying to topple the Empire. Pull back the X-Wing fighter to launch an epic squawk attack with Luke, Han, or Chewie birds (from the back of the box.) "Roll, Launch, Win!"

How many hits will it take the heroes to knock the pigs block off and explode the Death Star?

This is a new edition to the Jenga & Angry Birds line. The game comes with a Death Star frame, a Luke Skywalker bird, a Han Solo Bird, a Chewbacca bird, Darth Vader Pig, 4 Stormtrooper pigs, a X-Wing launcher, 31 plastic Jenga blocks, 1 lock block, 1 dice, label sheet, a game base,and game guide/setup card.

The object of the game is to destroy the Death Star. Roll the die to determine how many shots you can take & which birds to use. Alternate turns until the Death Star is destroyed.

Stormtrooper pigs = 1000 points each
Darth Vader pig = 3000 points
Complete destruction of the Death Star = 5000 points
Unlaunch birds after the Death Star is destroyed = 1000 points each.

The game is based on the Star Wars Angry Bird app. In addition, the game comes with a App code to unlock game content.

Hex Rampart is a variant of Rampart played on a hex hex board. Play starts with black. On his turn a player may either drop a stone of his color or remove a dead enemy group. Players may only legally drop stones adjacent to at least one of their stones already on the board. A group is considered dead if any stone within it has no adjacent empty cells. Removal of a group takes a whole turn. Removing own dead groups is strictly prohibited. Passing is prohibited unless a player has no legal move on his turn. The player to remove all enemy groups from the board is the winner.

item.description:
This is a roll-and-move spanish trivia game where players must answer only environmental questions at specific spaces to get progress toward victory, like in Trivial Pursuit. Same gameplay with different and cheaper components.



Un juego español al estilo Trivial Pursuit, pero sólo con preguntas relacionadas con el medio ambiente. Misma mecánica de juego con componentes diferentes, aunque más baratos.

A race game of motorbike that you have to ride your team to victory obtaining more points with your team.

Each player has a team of three motorbikes (Yellow, purple, red and green).
The aim of the game is to move all your team to gain the highest score by summing the result of the arrival of the 3 motorbikes.
The movement of each motorbike is done by a wheel with an arrow in the middle, at the turn player spins the arrow on the wheel, that will indicate how many squares move the 3 motorbikes.
The tactic is dodging oil spills, and take the wake of the bike in front of you.

[d0x3d!] is a cooperative game, for 2-4 players. Players assume the role of hackers, infiltrating a network. Together, you need to collect shares of digital assets and use these to re-capture stolen digital assets. Once you get all four digital assets, you and the other players need to escape the network, without getting caught. Each round, the admins patch the network and they may detect your intrusion. If the admins begin to suspect you are in their network: machines may get decommissioned for forensic investigation, the network threat level increases, and you or your friends might get caught.

item.description: The 4th Horse is a card game that combines the excitement of a fight to the finish with the intense strategy of chess. Two, three or four players may compete. Certain card combinations can be used to win bidding rounds or as special powers. The illustrations of cards are of a medieval style. There are 4 Horse Cards that can act as wild cards in their suits or if all 4 are played then the game can be won. Winning is also achieved by having 4 sequential royal cards of a suite and as the only player at the end of the turn to do so. Number cards can be played to attack when 4 cards in sequential order are played. Knives can remove cards of one suite from the play area, Thieves can steal all of a players cards, Swords can discard cards, Moon cards replicate other powers and also can eliminate a player. When playing cards, at least 2 cards in sequential order must be played. The challenge is deciding on whether to use the cards for their bidding value, save them to build sets or play them on the table to show people what you are collecting.

In the card game Mafia Casino, you want to be the first player to raise $30 million, whether through legal means (such as building hotels or casino resorts to attract clients who deal in pearls and diamonds) or means that fall on the shady side of legal (such as extorting someone or planting bombs in the hotels owned by opponents). The game lasts a number of rounds, and in each round players have a choice between building, gambling, conducting "business", or completing a mission.

Game description from the publisher:

Enter a world where money and the mafia go hand in hand. Build your Casino-Hotel and aim to become the richest. Attract prestigious guests, deal pearls and diamonds, and partake in games of chance. Spying, bombings, robbing safes, and embezzlement will help you sabotage the plans of your opponents. Be cautious though, there are no such things as “rules” in the Mafia.

item.description:
In this Garfield game all players have four pawns they must move around the board from their own start space to their own goal. Each side of the square shaped game board holds start and goal of one player colour. You throw one die on your turn and move that many spaces on the board. If you land on a space already occupied by another player's pawn, you get to bump that pawn back to start. If you land in a space where there is a picture of Garfield's paw, then you are safe and no pawns can be bumped back to start from those spaces.

First player to move all pawns of her colour to the goal wins the game.

item.description:
Dungeon Realms is nothing that is a card game for 2 players using deck-building mechanics in conjunction with the placement of workers, among others.

In Dungeon Realms, you play the role of an adventurer, inexperienced and novice of his hometown, eager challenges and adventures. Gradually, as the protagonist of the story, you have to explore (and plunder) with courage and bravery the region, facing many dangers and unimaginable adventures, thus gaining experience, reputation and social status and progress level.

Revive with courage, vigor and courage all the excitement of the adventures of an adventurer, palace intrigue and danger firsthand, and first-person protagonist of the adventures of an adventurer, bizarre, drunken and quarrelsome, in an exciting fantasy medieval district where they meet and are home to a multitude of stories, legends and fantastic tales.

Defy fate reaching for his sword, looking great treasures, and thieves' loot evil creatures, make the most powerful collection of magic items, descended into hell, look ultratumbas in ancient underground cities, check city distant dwarf king Aquilón , conspires palace, enjoyed in the company of your own Stag Tavern in between quarrels, hookahs and spicy wine bottles, performs missions for the king or for the thieves guild, save princesses and kill dragons. Only fame or death awaits.

You are a adventurer who tries to gather enough money and experience to become the next champion of the mark. Of course, you depend on the work of others to get the needed experience. You start with a set of 9 cards (6 of them are money, which give you 1 gold coin each and 3 cards to get 1 experience points (PXs)). Each round you draw 5 cards from your deck and use one card for the turn order to place your workers (adventurers marks). The workers go to the different building places in the Village to buy new cards for you (go and solve adventure), get experience or different other actions. Each turn there is one more space, where you can place your workers.

Also there is a Line of Events with 6 cards (quest and events representing), which you can choose to buy and each round the empty places in this row are filled from a deck of cards divided into 3 different "Ages" (the last two ages cost more gold coins).

The game ends in different ways: when a player reaches 100 px, or one player kills two dragons, or when no cards sufficient to fill the Line of Events.

[From the publisher's website]

1914, Serbien muß sterbien, The Initial Campaigns on the Balkan Front in WWI realistically covers the battles fought in and around Serbia during the first year of World War One.

1914, Serbien muß sterbien (an Austro-Hungarian jingle that translates to “Serbia must die”) is a comprehensively researched model that explores the intriguing set of campaigns fought in Serbia in 1914. The game includes an accurate order of battle and detailed game map. The map encompasses the primary theater of war from Peterwardein in the north, Sarajevo in the west, to Niš in the south-east.

The game system used is the same as found in 1914: Offensive Ã  outrance (GMT). The game has a playtested, concise, well written and organized 24-page rules booklet. 
1914, Serbien muß sterbien includes three sceanrios. Two short scenarios and a Grand Campaign scenario that covers the period from the initial Austro-Hungarian invasion in August to exhaustion a stalemate in December.

The game-design goal for 1914, Serbien muß sterbien is to produce an enjoyable game from which players can learn a great deal about the campaign and the geography of the theater of war. The result is a game that the "WW1 enthusiast" must have and that a gaming connoisseur will enjoy.

Game Scale:
The combat units are primarily Divisions and Brigades. The map’s scale is 1:500,000. Each hex is approximately 8 kilometers across, with the corresponding area being roughly 6475 hectares (or 16000 acres). Each game turn represents from two to four days of time depending on the season.

item.description:
It’s like Monopoly: Roll and move. Land on an unowned property: buy it. Land on an owned property: pay money to the owner.

It’s different from Monopoly: Only one die is used. The board is rectangular, with 10 spaces between the corners on the long edges and 6 spaces between the corners on the short edges.

It’s much less than Monopoly: No color groupings, therefore no monopolies. No house/hotel improvements. No utilities. No railroads. No auctions. No mortgages.

Victory conditions: Players are eliminated when they go bankrupt. The last player with money is the winner.

Players are Smurfs and race through the forest. First Smurf to reach the goal wins. Movement is controlled by a die. One side of the die has a picture of a raspberry glass. If you roll the glass, you collect one raspberry juice token from a face down pile. The token shows either a full glass or an empty glass. If you land on a special space on the game board, you will count your full juice glasses and advance that many steps. If you land on a space with Gargamel, you lose a turn.

item.description:
Turno consists of a hexagonal board divided into 96 triangles, with two players arranging thirty pieces (four cannons, eight bowmen, and three knights each) on their starting positions as marked on the board. Each piece has a red side and a gold side; players pick a color prior to starting and place their pieces with their chosen color facing up.

Players take turns moving. Pieces may be moved to unoccupied adjoining triangles (triangles that share a side, not a point.) After having moved, if an adjoining triangle is occupied with an opponent's piece, a player may announce an attack, which will result in a capture or a kill of that piece. Captured pieces are turned over to match the attacking player's color, killed pieces are removed from the board, never to return. (A captured piece may not be attacked for one turn.) The outcomes of attacks are determined as such:

Kill 
knight kills knight 
bowman kills bowman 
cannon kills cannon

Capture
knight captures bowman
bowman captures cannon
cannon captures knight

Players may prevent attack by moving a piece in danger to a triangle immediately next to a potential attacker. (Pieces must move before attacking.) The winning player captures or kills all of the opponent's pieces. One optional advanced rule is included, allowing knights to move through the small hexagons that cover the points of all the board's triangles.

item.description:
Game clock winding down, tie game, road team brings the ball up the court with the home crowd shrieking "DEE-FENSE, DEE-FENSE!" as the visitors try to get the rock in the hands of their top scorer for a possible game-winning shot. But pro basketball is a player's game, and sometimes the play that the coach designs doesn't work, so here comes a 20-foot jumper from the least likely shooter on the court as the clock is about to reach triple zeroes. The shot is true, tickling the net as the home crowd groans!

Is this a scene from any given night in the pro game? Absolutely – and it's also a scene that can happen with the same frequency when you play Basketball Bones, PT Games' new tabletop simulation of pro basketball using four dice ("bones") and player cards for a remarkably compact, efficient game engine in which very few charts are consulted and almost every possession is resolved by the dice and cards. Rebounding beasts, three point specialists, needle-threading passers and ham-handed, foul-prone defenders are all here, ready to perform for you on your tabletop as if it was made of hardwood. From the league's MVP to the 12th man on the worst team in the league, Basketball Bones rates every pro player in shooting percentage, field goal attempt frequency, rebounding, passing and more. The Rare Play charts introduce intangibles such as momentum swings, injuries, boneheaded decisions, and more!

Five treasures have sunk beneath the waves, and both players dive down from a recovery ship and try to be the first to recover three of them. Each turn, they roll the die and move exactly that many spaces if they can.

Published in Spielboexchen September 2012.

Monopoly: Zapped Edition updates the classic game by combining the attributes a board-game with the technology of an iPad/Phone/Pod Application. The APP is free and is quick and easy to download from the APP store. The basic mechanics of Monopoly are here, but with an updated look and no hard currency. Players use the app to buy and auction property, transfer money, pull Chance/Community Chest cards and take part in mini-games as play evolves. Each player has their own touch-banking cards which track their balances and allow for electronic transaction on your device.

Game Board comes with Rubber Pads, 6 tokens, 28 Property cards, 32 green houses, 12 red hotels, 2 dice, 4 Monopoly Touch-banking cards and instructions.

Note: An internet connection/iTunes account are required to download the app but not for game-play. App is in English language only.

Balance game with ice cream.

From the back of the box:

The intention of the game is for all 12 ice-cream balls to be stacked onto the cone. When it's your turn, you can select one ice-cream ball and use the ice-cream scoop to place it on the cone. Can you do it? Congratulations, you're a master ice-cream scooper. It's now the turn of the person sitting on your left. He or she can now use the ice-cream scoop to try and place one ice-cream ball on top of his or her predecessor's ball. You'll notice that the higher the tower, the more difficult it will get to keep the ice-cream tower upright!

When you drop on or several balls, your game is up. The others continue playing until all 12 ice-cream balls have been stacked. Does the entire tower fall over? The game is over and the person who let the tower fall is the loser!

item.description:
From the webpage

Dark Potential is a 28mm miniature wargame based in the post-apocalyptic near future of Earth.

Build up your chosen faction of miniatures ... and prepare to immerse yourself in a highly tactical skirmish-level wargame.

Will you fight for humanity's survival? Or will you side with the X'Lanthos menace? Or perhaps you don't really care for either, and will fight for the twisted Bioformed or the enigmatic Reclaimers?

Now you can decide the fate of the earth, and perhaps even humankind.

The games Indiegogo page related " is Dark Potential?

In short, it is a miniature wargame set in the near post-apocalyptic future of earth, roughly in the 2500s.

Humanity had managed to spread out to several other colonies in other systems, but then met with a hostile alien race that attempted to drive them back. This led to a war that annihilated both sides.

As most of humanity's population was still on Earth, the alien species (called the X'Lanthos) launched a virus meant to destroy all human life. Unfortunately for them it was only 99.99% effective, and left many survivors.

Those on earth revert to a basic survival mode, and nature starts reclaiming what was once hers."

The game is scheduled for release soon.

In Two Rooms and a Boom – a social deduction/hidden role party game for six or more players – there are two teams: the Red Team and the Blue Team. The Blue Team has a President. The Red Team has a Bomber. Players are equally distributed between two rooms (i.e., separate playing areas). The game consists of five timed rounds. At the end of each round, some players will be swapped into opposing rooms. If the Red Team's Bomber is in the same room as the President at the end of the game, then the Red Team wins; otherwise the Blue Team wins. Lying encouraged.

item.description:
Battle of Oshi-jou is fought in1590.
This is part of Hideyoshi's Odawara campaign.
The game focuses only the siege battle of Oshi-jou.

The game uses turn sequence. In each turn, each side has movement, fire then melee. In each turn, Hohjo side can decide to go first or last, since they have home-town benefit.
The game starts July 1st turn and end July 17th turn.
Hideyoshi side must either conquer Hon-maru or eliminate Narita Nagachika until the game end.

DTP game.
1 map, 1 rulebook, 2 countersheet.

link.value: Dōjin Club Ludens Faber (同人会ルデンス・ファベル)

item.description:
The conflicts in Aventurien are as varied as the world itself. Now there is a new way to sort out these battles.

In Schicksalspfade rivaling groups of adventurers hired by warring rulers fight in miniature combats for power, honour and the right to claim their destiny.

Fight with the brave Stars of the Reichsarmee for the Empress, justice and the Empire, strengthen the influence of Al’Anfa with the Order of the Hand of Boron, loot and plunder with the tough Ottajasko or solve long forgotten secrets with the mysterious Tulamidian Riders of Fasar and get help from the different Heroes and Rogues of Aventurien who also want their part of the treasure. The secrets of Aventurien are yours to discover, so use your chance to wander the paths that determine your future and your destiny.

Schicksalspfade (Paths of Destiny) is a skirmish miniature combat game based on the RPG Das Schwarze Auge (The Dark Eye). The system is a standalone game in which you lead your party of adventurers into the battlefield. The Rulebook includes 28 characters from five different fractions that have unique abilities. Build your own party and lead it into challenging and exciting scenarios.
In a standard game each player has about 4 to 6 characters and it lasts about 60 minutes and takes ten turns.

Now available:
- The Rulebook which includes everything you need to play (Rules, maps and paper miniatures to cut out) except the 20 sided dice
- The Cardset which includes the maps, tokens and characters from the Rulebook printed on fine Cardboard
- Tin miniatures for each of the starting characters


Die Konflikte in der Welt von Das Schwarze Auge sind so vielfältig wie Aventurien selbst. Entdecke nun eine neue Art und Weise, diese Gefechte auszutragen.

Bei Schicksalspfade wetteifern rivalisierende Abenteurergruppen im Dienste verfeindeter Herren in Miniaturengefechten um Macht, Ruhm, Ehre und das Recht, ihr Schicksal selbst zu bestimmen.

Streite mit den tapferen Sternen der Reichsarmee für Kaiserin, Recht und Reich, mehre den Einfluss Al’Anfas mit der geheimnisvollen Hand Borons, raube und brandschatze mit der raubeinigen Ottajasko aus Thorwal oder entschlüssele längst vergangene Geheimnisse mit den mysteriösen Tulamidischen Reitern aus Fasar. Suche die Hilfe der zahlreichen Helden & Schurken Aventuriens, die ebenfalls ihren Teil vom Kuchen für sich beanspruchen. Die Geheimnisse Aventuriens warten auf dich. Also greif zu und begib dich auf die Pfade, die deine Zukunft, dein Schicksal bestimmen werden.

A game of early California, from the Spanish explorers to the Gold Rush.

Players take turns exploring and settling California, developing local industries. The game starts with the earliest explorers, like Cabrillo and de Anza. The early pioneers make a living shipping goods (like hides) overseas. Later on, California becomes settled enough to develop markets of its own.

Presidios help defend against danger and establish the governing power's control over the region. Missions convert the California Indians into Spanish settlements. El Camino Real is built, connecting the settlements of California together.

Thorin Oakenshield's quest to reclaim the Dwarven Kingdom of Erebor takes his brave band of Dwarves - accompanied by the Hobbit, Bilbo Baggins, and the mysterious Wizard, Gandalf the Grey - far across the trackless wilderness of Middle-earth.

This is a 25 mm Miniature wargame that features; collecting, painting and conversion of miniature figures used in play, as well as the modeling of gaming terrain. Using D6 dice to resolve the actions and moving by tape measuring.

The standard game is played with two or more armies on a board generally 4 feet long and 4 feet wide (48 inches or 120 centimetres), usually deployed within 6 inches of opposite board edges. Played in several scenarios developing the story of the hobbits escape of the Oks town.

item.description:
Space Race style board game where the objective is to land all your spacecraft on the moon first. Roll of the dice and move game,

Players becomes Astronauts, passing Astronaut training by throwing a double. He then moves a spacecraft onto the launch pads and moves the spaces by roll of the dice. Another doube thow can move another spaceship onto the launch pad. As they circle around the moon they progess into number of orbits (i.e. 1st, 2nd, 3rd orbit). Spacecraft in the final 3rd orbit may shoot for the moon, go into a lunar orbit and successfully touch down.

Publisher Eugenia Doughtie, 907 Marshall, Houston, Texas

Spacecraft can be captured by landing on an opponents ship Spacecraft may also land on Mercury communication or solar communication cards and follow directions. Spacecraft may get lost in outer space

Tiddlywink style game where small plastic rings (flying saucers)are place on a launcher at an angle. The ring is pressed down with a flat disc to propel the ring into a playing board set at an angle 2 to 3 feet away.

The object is that players shoot at the board showing the moon and planets. Players score points for landing on the moon, in moon craters, on moon mountains or on planets. The first to reach 250 points is declared to winner.

Not dated but would be a 1960s game based on graphics

Warren Built - Rite game, No 8600, Lafayette, Indiana, USA

This game is intended for children to teach them endangered plant and animal species.

There is a spinner in the middle of the game board and boxes representing different species on the edge.

In his turn player spins the arrow and draws a card. If the arrow points either the animal or the habitat, or the threat with other cards player has, he keeps the card and plays it in front of him. If the player is mistaken for a complete series, it must discard all cards of this series! 
The winner is the one who has got the most cards if the deck is exhausted..
Many other variants are available.

There are area of Northeast of France seen on the gameboard, with its main cities, 3 tours crisscrossing the region, and beautiful photos!
Each player chooses a circuit (Architecture-Culture-History, Economics, Gourmet or Nature) and places his token on one of the cities. Everyone gets three tourist tickets (1 point each) and must travel 20 cities on its circuit.
 If player reaches a stage town, the player responds to a question. In case of right answer, the player receives 1 to 3 points depending on the difficulty of the question. Competitors move either box by box, or by using a special die to extend 2 to 5 space (do not exceed your goal).

The game ends when a player has completed his circuit. 
The winner is the player who scores the most points on the tourist tickets

Simple top style game where opponets have to hand held tops that they manually spin on a game board. The board has the planets with holes in the middle of them. The objective is the base of the top falls into the planet holes and players score points. First player to a set value (i.e. 1000 points is declared the winner.

Not dated posiibly 1970s

The object is to discover Paris and win the maximum monuments.

The board represents Paris with its main sites, their values â€‹â€‹ranging from 1 to 5 points (only the Eiffel Tower is worth 5 points). Each site is represented on a nice place on its support site plan.
Each player places his token on a starting point. Rolling "6" is required to start nad in his turn player rolls the dice and move on the board-grid and try to reach beyond the monuments.

Once a player reaches a certain score (6 to 16 points depending on the number of players), he must go to the foot of the Eiffel Tower. To take the symbol of Paris, the player must make roll "1" or "2" depending on the position of the game-piece from the Tour.
The Eiffel Tower taken, the game ends. The winner is the player who scores the most points.

Each player has seven pawns with hole on top and a ball.
One player put the ball

In his turn, Player may move two of his pawns. If he has the ball, he must place the ball to hole of another pawn at the end of his move.
Pawns may move one of two ways.
adjacent square or jump over other pawn vertically, horisontally or diagonally.

The goal is to place the ball past the opposing line.

Small frogs are balancing on the waterlilies. Careful they don't fall into the pond! A game that encourages communication between toddlers and their parents.
(From the publisher)

Players will cooperatively place stilts, upon which they balance waterlilies. The more dexterous the kids, the more stilts and waterlilies you can use. Players can choose to start a new tower, or continue an existing one. If the players run out of stilts and lilies, a frog is placed on top to finish the tower.
If all elements are placed and the towers still stand, each player receives a point.

Simple roll and move game, starting from earth the objective is the first to reach mars.

No date but graphics suggest late 50s early 60s

From the publisher's website:
This game will wip your flig (flip your wig)! Sometimes known as a spoonerism, we’ve renamed this clever wordplay exercise Splickety Lit. Each question has words or phrases that have their beginning fonsonants clipped (consonants flipped…you pet the gicture). The challenge is to answer the Splickety Lit question correctly in the mame sanner. So, if asked who Skuke Lywalker’s father was, you can confidently shout out (spoiler alert) "Varth Dader!” Engaging your memory, word skills, and comprehension speed, Splickety Lit is a winner that’ll keep everyone guessing, from fart to stinish!

item.description:
In The Little Prince: Make Me a Planet, each player will build his own planet to provide a beautiful home for the dear animals of The Little Prince – the fox, the sheep, the elephant and the snake – but make sure there aren't too many volcanoes and baobab trees!

Each round, the start player chooses one of the four stacks of tiles and takes as many tiles as the number of players. He chooses one of them and appoints a different player to choose another tile. This new player takes the tile and starts building her own planet in front of her. Then she appoints another player, and so on, until every player gets a tile. The last player must take the only tile that remains. To make up for that, this player becomes the start player for the next round.

Baobab trees grow on some tiles, and having too many of them is bad. If a player has three baobab trees on his planet, the three tiles bearing these trees have to be turned face down. Now the items on those tiles won't score you points at the end of the game!

By the end of the game, four characters will be located around each player's planet, earning that player points based on the various items present on the planet. Not everything is risk-free, though, as the player who has the highest number of volcanoes loses as many points as the number of volcanoes on his planet. The player with the highest score wins!

name.value: Iron Age: Council of the Clans

item.description:
In this tabletop political strategy game, players compete and co-operate with each other to create a community. Players gain honour by growing and managing their villages, and by interacting with other players. The more honour they gain, the better their position at the Landsmoot, a special democratic assembly where players vote for a Chieftain. Win the Landsmoot often enough, and you win the game as a whole.

Iron Age was originally developed by a professor of philosophy to teach political science to his students. From the "soft power" of culture, trade, and diplomacy, to the "hard power" of the army, nearly every facet of real world politics is reproduced in this game.

Rollaway is an abstract dice game about picking the right time to play whatever actions you roll. The interaction of six simple actions (win, lose, skip, double, give, and take) produces a rich variety of gameplay. A die that normally scores one point could earn you four, or could be taken away. You might use a skip-die to prevent the next player from giving you a burdensome lose-die, or you might take the lose-die so you can pass it on to someone else. Rollaway is simple to learn, highly interactive, and provides hours of lightly strategic fun.

Struck's shape shifting checkerboard will offer new and puzzling challenges with each game you play. To win, all four of your playing pieces must occupy the four goals at the opposing end of the board.

The amount of moves each player will make during their turn is determined by the roll of the unique Struck Die. A "move" can be one of three actions: move a playing piece, change the color of a playing piece, or change the color on the checkerboard. By rolling three or higher, all actions can be used during a turn.

This four-player post apocalyptic board game leads gamers on the journey with Kai, making decisions that could impact the survival of the human race. In the aftermath of the apocalypse, survivors were forced to make decisions about how to rebuild our society. After Time: Survival follows the adventures of Kai, one of the lucky few who escaped from the crumbling civilization. But Kai's journey was not without its struggles, as he finds himself without a family, caring for a little girl who had lost hers as well, and is expected to lead a group of survivors in the rebuilding process. Faced with widespread hunger, dangerous weather conditions, and the dark temptations of personal greed, Kai's wits will be tested as he leads his group to a better life.

The board has a simple roll and move mechanic but when the players land on a "running Kai" space they draw a "Survival" card. On the card is a piece of the story that has an encounter that has two choices. The Player reads the card and then must choose an option and then turn the card over to see if they have earned community points or resource points. As they move around the board they might be hit by storms. The storms will set them back if they have no shelter token. Shelter tokens are earned when the player builds a community house.

Players compete as they race to amass resource points to build their own houses; but then the game takes a turn when they have to cooperate and negotiate with each other to spend and/or pool their community points to build community houses.

The winner of the game is the person who has been helpful enough to get all of the community houses built but has also balanced their own needs and has completed building their own five individual houses.

This is a game of intense, steampunk-airship battle and daring rescue. Players work together to overcome an evil squad of airfoils while attempting to rescue The Grand Duchess from the battleship Kre'null. 
 
Escape of the Kre'null is a strategic cooperative arial combat game where 1 to 4 players work together in an effort to reach The Grand Duchess while fighting off enemy airships. Upon reaching the Kre'null the players must search for, rescue, and escape with The Grand Duchess before being knocked out of the sky or failing to reach the Kre'null entirely.

The game allows players to:
- use various charts to create their ships
- select from over 12 game board layouts 
- coordinate actions while dealing with various random events
- take turns making strategic decisions during aerial combat
- support the game's enemy AI system as it tries to defeat the players

All in a day’s work you say? What are you waiting for? Jump into one of the Naruil Airfoils and head off into adventure!

What color is Pac-Man? What was Nintendo doing back in the year 1800?

BitQuiz is a trivia card game sporting 500 questions on computer and video games where each card holds five questions suitable for anyone, with the Difficulty Mode ranging from Easy all the way up to Nightmare.

Phantom Leader – Solitaire

What’s New in the Deluxe Edition?
We have expanded and updated the original Phantom Leader game to the high standard set by our Hornet Leader game.

Increase the cards from 165 to 330 
- All pilots get all 6 experience levels 
- Add new aircraft: Air Force F-5, Air Force A-7 
- Add more pilots for all aircraft types 
- Add more Target cards 
- Add more Special Event cards 
- Revise the 6 original Campaigns to include the new Targets and Aircraft

Add Air Force and Navy Campaigns for the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis

Upgrade to a mounted 11"x17" Tactical Display

Description:
Phantom Leader places you in command of a US Air Force or US Navy Tactical Fighter squadron in Vietnam between 1964 and 1972. You must not only destroy the targets but you must also balance the delicate political repercussions of your attacks. If you strike too hard, your air offensive might be put on hold, strike to light, and you’ll be blamed for losing the war.

Welcome to the Vietnam Air War!

Each of the campaigns can be played with either an Air Force or Navy squadron. The targets assigned to each service are different and change the complexion of the campaigns. Each campaign can be played with three different durations of: Skirmish, Conflict, or War.

Each mission takes roughly 30 minutes to set-up, plan, and resolve.

Each of your pilots has their own skills. Selecting the right pilots and weapons for a mission is vital to its success. As you fly missions, your pilots will gain experience and fatigue. With experience, their skills improve, but as their fatigue increases, their skills decrease and they might not be able to fly for several missions.

For those of you familiar with our modern era Hornet Leader series of games, you might be wondering what’s different about Phantom Leader…

The freedom of being able to select the best mission based on military objectives is something that is commonplace for today’s military. Back in Vietnam, the military was responsible for carrying out their orders, while at the same time being extremely limited in the weapons and tactics they were allowed to use to complete those orders. In many cases, the specific weapons, approach paths, and bombing altitudes were generated target-by-target at the White House. The mission specifics were then sent down the chain of command to the individual pilots flying the mission. As you can imagine, this was not the best way to run an air campaign.

Every target has a Political value. If you destroy it, you move the Political counter to the right a number of spaces equal to its value. As the counter gets moved to the right, your future target choices are reduced to those that are less politically sensitive. Which target you choose not to attack is also important. You get to move the Political counter to the left a number of spaces equal its Political value.

This means that while you might like to flatten a big enemy target and rack up the victory points, it might be better for you to choose a pointless target and move the Political counter in your favor instead.

Another difference is in combat power. For the last couple decades, the US Air Force and Navy have enjoyed air superiority due to training and technology. Such was not the case in the skies over Vietnam. The enemy had different, but just as capable, equipment. They also had the training and will to use it to its utmost.

They soon became aware of the limitations placed on the US forces by the politicians, and used those limitations to their advantage.

For example, at times, US pilots were not permitted to fire on enemy aircraft until they were visually identified. This negated any range advantage conveyed by the radar-homing AIM-7 Sparrow missiles. It was also a common limitation that enemy aircraft could only be attacked in the air. US pilots were not allowed to attack enemy airbases. US aircraft were also limited to flying predictable flight paths, at set times. This made setting up ambushes much easier for the enemy.

So, while you might be a Hornet Leader ace, Vietnam is a whole different ballgame!

If player reaches a stage town, the player responds to a question. In case of right answer, the player receives 1 to 3 points depending on the difficulty of the question. Competitors move either box by box, or by using a special die to extend 2 to 5 space (do not exceed your goal).

The game ends when a player has completed his circuit.

There is a La Moselle in the game board what is a department in the east of France named after the river Moselle.

Each player chooses a circuit (Architecture-Culture-History, Economics, Gourmet or Nature) and places his token on one of the places. Everyone gets three tourist tickets (1 point each) and must travel 20 cities on its circuit.

There is a La Marne in the game board what is a commune in the Loire-Atlantique department in western France.

If player reaches a stage town, the player responds to a question. In case of right answer, the player receives 1 to 3 points depending on the difficulty of the question. Competitors move either box by box, or by using a special die to extend 2 to 5 space (do not exceed your goal).

The game ends when a player has completed his circuit.

A set of medieval miniature wargaming rules intended for 28mm miniatures but playable in any scale.

Units consist of 12 foot or 6 mounted miniatures, which are used to fight out skirmish battles between armies of 4-6 units per side.

Units need to be activated by dice rolls which are easier to pass if you choose orders well suited to that particular troop type. For example, knights will charge more easily than other troops, and archers are easier to command to shoot rather than charge.

The rules are simple and to some extent they abstract medieval battle in favor of easy game play.

item.description:
"My life is mine?" is a cardgame themed on life. One player will be the protagonist of the game. He and all other players use cards to write the destiny of the protagonist. Each card will have a part of your life. The game is divided into four seasons (child, youth, adult, elderly). At the end of each cycle, the cards played are checked to know what really happens in the protagonist's life and that will not happen. Points are earned with the cards that were successful. At the end of the game, whoever has the most points is the winner.

Will the protagonists be able to have command of your own life and win in the end? Or is that the other players will determine how it will be his life?

This is a fast game, created for fun, involving a bit of memorization, bluff and strategy. And luck, of course, exists in all of our lives (or not!). Enjoy it!

Ps.: Sorry for my english. It isn't my native language.

item.description:
Looks like a Connect 4 Launchers but reduced to a single deck.

Players each have sixteen chips they try to shoot to board in proper holes in their turn.
Player who get 4 in a row is the winner.

Who will win Employee of the Day? Deal with customers, the register, shipping and stocking. The 18 hour day begins with a roll of the dice . . .

2 players, 3d6 and 20 markers per player :: the player with the most VP at game end wins!

Setup: Decide who is Player 1 and Player 2. Each player takes 20 markers in one color. Next, lay the cards out in a line between players, in order from (1)-(6), creating the game store. One of the players places a marker on the 17 space on the (6) card. Player 1 begins.

Play: Players take turns rolling/re-rolling 3d6 up to three times, keeping any dice they wish during each roll (you may re-roll previously kept dice except for any 6s). Once the 3 dice rolls are done, the player can apply any die or set of dice to match various options on the game store cards. Players will place markers of their color on the cards over the smaller dice and cube icons. Each die rolled has a different meaning in the game.

Game End: Total each player’s VP. The player with the most VP wins. In the case of a tie, whichever player has majority on the [1] card is the winner.

This is the 2nd in a series of Annual Games Unlimited Holiday Games (2012) and is the followup to Gameshop Express (2011)

item.description:
Introduction from the rules sheet:
Birdorama can be played by one person as a 'Patience', or by 2, 3 or 4 players. In each case the principle is the same - to build up a 'panoramic' picture, three pieces deep, in which each piece contributes to the scene by correctly joining and continuing from its neighbours at all touching edges, as in a jig-saw.

Birdorama can be played by 2, 3 or 4 players. Each player takes 9 tiles (plus the 'Rarity' tile) at random from his set of 24 to make his hand. Players take turn to lay tiles (in legal positions) until either one player lays his last tile or no-one can lay a legal tile. Tiles left in the hand are then scored, and the winner is the player with the fewest points.

HikyÅ na kÅmori ("Cowardly Bat") is a card game of bluffing in which players try to piggy-back on other players' cards to score the most points.

All cards are dealt to the players. Each round players take turns playing a card on the table one by one and announce whether it is a Beast or a Bird. Cards may be played face up or face down, and players are free to lie about the card they have played. After each player has a card on the table, face-down cards are revealed and the outcome of the round is determined:


 If all cards are the same type: Everyone wins a point.
 If cards are of two types, then if there are only Beasts and Birds, the side with the most cards wins a point. If, however, there are Bats and anything else, the side that is not the Bats wins a point.
 If cards are of all three types, then if there is a majority of Beasts or Birds, the side with the most cards and the Bats get a point. Otherwise if the number of Beasts and Birds is the same, they all get a point and the Bats get nothing.


Play continues until players run out of cards. The player with the most points wins.

item.description:
Game published on the back cover to the Knockout Fun Book in 1956.

The rules: To play this thrilling game, you need a die, a dice cup (an egg-cup will do) and some coloured counters or buttons for aeroplanes {one for each player). Any number of players can take part, and the first to touch down on square 52 is the winner. With your last throw of the die you must get the exact number to reach 52 - if you throw too high a number you must wait another turn. We're sure that you’ll enjoy this game as much as you enjoy Cadburys Milk Cnocolate.

Tower is a set collection game for 2-4 players who want to race to beat their opponents to stores and buy the resources they need before the stores are out of stock. Resources are purchased with jewels, which players draw from the black bag at the start of their turns. The players then use their purchased resources to construct segments of the tower. The first player to construct all three of his tower segments wins!

A big theme of Tower is scarcity of resources, with only 18 resources in a four-player game. It's likely that in any given play session there will be enough resources for only one player, forcing everyone to play dirty in order to come out on top.

The black market provides a source for players to hire thugs to carry out some pretty shady actions. These range from intimidation, to stealing resources from other players, and robbing Salil, the tax collector. It's a dirty job, but it's necessary in order to succeed in Tower.

item.description:
This Looney Pyramid game uses Volcano mechanics in an arrangment and manner inspired by Enochian Chess. Abiegnus is played on a 5x4 board that is set up to emulate the Tablet of Union from the system of angelic magic developed by Elizabethan adepts John Dee and Edward Kelly.

The name Abiegnus is from the mystical mountain of the Rosicrucian brotherhood.

Options and variants for this game include solitaire and competetive play, divination (fortune-telling), and different color schemes to support variant occult traditions.

item.description:
Run with the Pack is a fast paced card game of survival. The game takes place over the course of a single night in the forest. Players start out as lone wolves and fight to have the largest pack by the time the sun comes up.

The goal of Run with the Pack is to build your wolf pack and have the highest amount of wolves when the deck is exhausted. This is done by attracting wolves with Prey cards and gaining them into your pack by using Howl or Calls in the Night cards. You can also attack the other players’ packs by using Intimidate cards.

Auction House is a game for 2-6 players played over 2-3 turns where 6 lots are bid for each turn. For each lot players submit a secret value token that collectively equals the value for that lot. Players then bid in turn until all but one player have passed. The value is then revealed. If the value is greater than the bid, the winner moves the difference forward on the track. If the value is less he moves back. The winner collects the item token.

After six lots have been auctioned a new turn is commenced with players taking back their value tokens and lots returned for new bids. At the end of the agreed number of turns, the player furthest in profit wins.

The game is hand made from wood and comes in its own self contained hinged box with the board carved onto the lid.

item.description:
Nobody wants to be holding the egg (= an egg-shaped, battery-powered timer) when it cracks. To get rid of it, the active player has to name a word that fits a category from the current card, e.g. "pizza toppings". He/she then passes it on to the next player or returns it to the player he/she got it from. The player who is holding the egg when it makes a cracking sound loses the current round. He/she gets the current topic card and starts a new round by turning over the top card from the stack.
A player who has collected three cards is eliminated from the game. The game continues until there is only one player left. This player wins the game.
If a player uses a word that another player has already used this round (and the other players notice), he has to keep the egg until he/she can think of another suitable word.

Diamanttjuven (Diamond thief) is a stand-alone sequel to Afrikan tÃ¤hti, where the fiamond is stolen from the owner of the diamond, a princess. But out there in the dark all thieves looking alike, and there will be a number of thieves. By rolling a spinner you will get the possibility to either draw a card, drive your pink car or do both. The aim of the game is to catch thieves.
